prs.title: fix(locale): show correct prefix instead of [object Object] in AZ and ES language

reviews.body:
> [!CAUTION] > Inline review comments failed to post. This is likely due to GitHub's limits when posting large numbers of comments. If you are seeing this consistently it is likely a permissions issue. Please check "Moderation" -> "Code review limits" under your organization settings. **Actionable comments posted: 21**
üõë Comments failed to post (21)
ERROR_HANDLING.md (2)
188-197: _üõ†Ô∏è Refactor suggestion_ **Fix typo and add Traditional Chinese example** There's a typo (`deafult`) and the example only shows Persian (`fa.js`). Since this PR introduces Traditional Chinese, update the spelling and include a `zh-tw` locale import: ```diff -There are locale-specific error maps built into Zod for various languages. To set the deafult error map based on your locale, you can import the error map from the `zod/locales` directory. +There are locale-specific error maps built into Zod for various languages. To set the default error map for your locale, import it from the `zod/locales` directory. -```ts -import { z } from "zod"; -import errorMap from "zod/locales/fa.js"; +```ts +import { z } from "zod"; +import errorMap from "zod/locales/zh-tw.js"; z.setErrorMap(errorMap); ``` ``` This aligns the docs with the new Traditional Chinese support. --- 43-57: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Remove inline HTML `
` and update link fragment for consistency** Markdownlint flags the use of `
` tags as inline HTML (MD033). We should replace these with Markdown-native line breaks (two spaces at end of line) or use list syntax within table cells. Also, the fragment link `(#Customizing-errors-with-ZodErrorMap)` should be all lowercase to match the generated slug (`#customizing-errors-with-zoderrormap`). Example diff on one table row: ```diff -| `expected: ZodParsedType`
`received: ZodParsedType`

Jump to [this section](#zodparsedtype) for a breakdown... +| `expected: ZodParsedType` +`received: ZodParsedType` + +Jump to [this section](#zodparsedtype) for a breakdown... ``` And update the link in the `custom` row: ```diff -| ...see [ZodErrorMap](#Customizing-errors-with-ZodErrorMap) below... +| ...see [ZodErrorMap](#customizing-errors-with-zoderrormap) below... ``` > Committable suggestion skipped: line range outside the PR's diff.
üß∞ Tools
ü™õ LanguageTool [style] ~57-~57: As a shorter alternative for ‚Äòable to‚Äô, consider using ‚Äúcan‚Äù. Context: ...hrow issues of any `ZodIssueCode`). You are able to pass in a `params` object here that is ... (BE_ABLE_TO)

link-fragments)
.github/pull_request_template.md (1)
3-3: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Fix typo in contributor message** There's a small typo in "Thanks for contribting to OSS!"‚Äîlet's fix that to "contributing." ```diff - Thanks for contribting to OSS! + Thanks for contributing to OSS! ```
üìù Committable suggestion > ‚ÄºÔ∏è **IMPORTANT** > Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements. `````suggestion Development of the next major version of Zod (`v4`) is currently underway. During this phase, only bugfixes and documentation improvements are being accepted into the `main` branch. All other PRs should target the `v4` branch. Thanks for contributing to OSS! `````
README.md (3)
117-117: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Fix broken anchor link case in heading** The anchor link in the TOC (`#zodtype-with-ZodTransform`) doesn't match the actual fragment format. The `ZodTransform` part should be lowercase for HTML anchors to work properly. ```diff - - [ZodType with ZodTransform](#zodtype-with-ZodTransform) + - [ZodType with ZodTransform](#zodtype-with-zodtransform) ```
üìù Committable suggestion > ‚ÄºÔ∏è **IMPORTANT** > Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements. `````suggestion - [ZodType with ZodTransform](#zodtype-with-zodtransform) `````
üß∞ Tools
ü™õ markdownlint-cli2 (0.17.2) 117-117: Link fragments should be valid Expected: #zodtype-with-zodtransform; Actual: #zodtype-with-ZodTransform (MD051, link-fragments)
--- 769-770: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Typo in IP address documentation** This looks like a typo - "IP 6" should probably be "IPv6" to be technically correct. ```diff -The `z.string().ip()` method by default validate IPv4 and IP 6. +The `z.string().ip()` method by default validates IPv4 and IPv6. ``` Note that I also fixed "validate" to "validates" for grammar.
üìù Committable suggestion > ‚ÄºÔ∏è **IMPORTANT** > Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements. `````suggestion The `z.string().ip()` method by default validates IPv4 and IPv6. `````
--- 1783-1785: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Missing parenthesis in text** There seems to be a missing closing parenthesis after the opening one. ```diff -When using `z.ZodType` with `z.ZodTransform` ( +When using `z.ZodType` with `z.ZodTransform` ( [`.refine`](https://github.com/colinhacks/zod#refine), [`.transform`](https://github.com/colinhacks/zod#transform), ``` > Committable suggestion skipped: line range outside the PR's diff.
üß∞ Tools
ü™õ LanguageTool [uncategorized] ~1784-~1784: A punctuation mark might be missing here. Context: ...ing `z.ZodType` with `z.ZodTransform` ( [`.refine`](https://github.com/colinhacks... (AI_EN_LECTOR_MISSING_PUNCTUATION) --- [uncategorized] ~1785-~1785: A punctuation mark might be missing here. Context: ...ps://github.com/colinhacks/zod#refine), [`.transform`](https://github.com/colinha... (AI_EN_LECTOR_MISSING_PUNCTUATION)
.github/workflows/test.yml (2)
25-29: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Adopt pnpm in the Node test job** Switching from Yarn to pnpm here is spot on. To speed up CI, consider adding an `actions/cache` step for the pnpm store. --- 42-45: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Adopt pnpm in the lint job** Nice pnpm migration for linting. As above, caching the pnpm store can drastically cut runtime.
.github/workflows/release.yml (2)
27-31: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Use pnpm for dependencies in release job** Switching install steps to pnpm is consistent with the rest of the repo. Similar to test, you can speed this up by caching the pnpm store. --- 22-22: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Remove trailing spaces** YAML lint flagged a trailing space here. You can trim it for a clean CI run. ```diff - + ```
üìù Committable suggestion > ‚ÄºÔ∏è **IMPORTANT** > Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements. `````suggestion `````
üß∞ Tools
ü™õ YAMLlint (1.35.1) [error] 22-22: trailing spaces (trailing-spaces)
.vscode/launch.json (1)
7-21: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **VSCode Node debug configuration** This setup will let you debug TS files with `--experimental-strip-types` nicely. You might add a `preLaunchTask` (e.g. `"pnpm build"`) to auto-compile before hitting breakpoints. ```jsonc // Example addition: "preLaunchTask": "pnpm build", ```
.npmrc (1)
1-4: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Workspace package settings in `.npmrc`** Linking workspace packages and disabling hoisting fits pnpm monorepos. You can either remove or document the commented-out `prefer-workspace-packages` line if you won‚Äôt enable it.
CONTRIBUTING.md (2)
30-33: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Updated setup instructions to use `pnpm`** Nice switch to `pnpm i` and `pnpm play`. For consistency, pick either the shorthand or full `pnpm install` everywhere in the docs. --- 73-75: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Testing guidelines enhanced** Great guidance on Vitest and pre-push hooks. You might link directly to the `tests` directory (e.g., `tests/`) to help newcomers find it faster.
.configs/rollup.config.js (2)
8-13: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Double‚Äëcheck your entry & output paths** Using `./scratch/input.ts` ‚Üí `./scratch/out_rollup.js` is fine for quick experiments, but if this is your library‚Äôs official build you might want to point at `src/index.ts` ‚Üí `dist/index.esm.js`. Also consider uncommenting `sourcemap: true` for better dev debug. --- 14-19: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Plugin order & externals** The order (`resolve()` ‚Üí `commonjs()` ‚Üí `typescript()`) usually works, but I've seen folks flip `typescript()` before `commonjs()` to avoid CJS/ES export quirks. Also think about adding an `external: [...]` array so peer deps don‚Äôt get bundled.
.vscode/settings.json (1)
12-20: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **files.exclude & search.exclude** You‚Äôve hidden the usual build folders (`.tshy-build`, `dist`, `lib`) and explicitly included `./scratch`, which matches the Rollup config. If you add other temp dirs later (like `coverage`), you might need to flip those flags too.
.configs/tsconfig.base.json (1)
25-33: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Decorators & pretty** If you‚Äôre not heavy on decorators, you could drop `emitDecoratorMetadata`/`experimentalDecorators`. Also `pretty` only affects CLI output; feel free to remove if it clutters CI logs.
biome.jsonc (3)
2-7: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Formatter basics** Spaces + `lineWidth: 120` is ü§ô. If you want to be extra explicit, you can add `"indentWidth": 2` or 4 to lock in your space count. --- 61-75: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Ignored files** The ignore list is pretty thorough. If you find yourself accidentally linting files in `scratch`, you may want to add it here too. --- 18-59: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Linter rules** You‚Äôve turned off a bunch of suspicious/style rules to keep DX smooth, but consider re‚Äëenabling auto-fixable ones like `noUnusedImports` or at least setting its `fix` to `"unsafe"` so you don‚Äôt ship dead code.

`23-50`: _üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_ **Consider removing or archiving commented steps** You‚Äôve commented out the build and publish steps, which is probably intentional, but leftover commented blocks can get noisy over time. ü™õ LanguageTool
ERROR_HANDLING.md [style] ~57-~57: As a shorter alternative for ‚Äòable to‚Äô, consider using ‚Äúcan‚Äù. Context: ...hrow issues of any `ZodIssueCode`). You are able to pass in a `params` object here that is ... (BE_ABLE_TO)

üîá Additional comments (44)
LICENSE (1) `3-3`: **Nice catch: bumped the copyright year to 2025** Keeping the license header up-to-date is important‚Äîthis looks all good.
ERROR_HANDLING.md (4) `43-55`: **Table formatting and existing entries look solid üëç** The markdown table header and alignment are clear, and all pre-existing error code entries are accurately documented and well formatted. --- `56-56`: **New `invalid_intersection_types` entry is spot‚Äëon** The addition of `ZodIssueCode.invalid_intersection_types` with its `mergeErrorPath` field and description matches the implementation and reads correctly. --- `188-189`: **Kudos on the new "Locales" section** Introducing a dedicated "Locales" section is a great way to document how to plug in language‚Äëspecific error maps. --- `192-197`: **Code snippet for locale import looks good** The TypeScript example showing `import errorMap from "zod/locales/fa.js";` and `z.setErrorMap(errorMap);` correctly demonstrates how to apply a locale‚Äëspecific map.
.prettierrc.yaml (1) `6-6`: **Ensure support for experimental ternaries.** Turning on `experimentalTernaries` is neat, but since it‚Äôs still experimental, double‚Äëcheck that your formatter (Biome, IDE, etc.) and the rest of the team have enabled and agreed on using this option.
.changeset/config.json (1) `1-11`: **Changesets configuration looks solid.** The `.changeset/config.json` correctly references the v3 schema, disables automatic commits, and scopes internal dependency bumps to patch versions. Everything aligns with the new release workflow.
MIGRATION.md (1) `59-59`: **Docs updated to reflect `ZodTransform`.** Replacing `ZodEffects` with `ZodTransform` here keeps the migration guide in sync with the updated class name used throughout the docs.
README_ZH.md (2) `1250-1250`: **Corrected to use `z.ZodType`.** Updating the cast from `z.ZodSchema` to `z.ZodType` aligns with the upstream API and matches the English docs. --- `1303-1305`: **Apply `z.ZodType` for JSON schema.** Switching the JSON schema declaration to `z.ZodType` maintains consistency with transform/refinement terminology.
.npmrc (1) `1-4`: **npm workspace config looks solid** Enabling `link-workspace-packages` with hoisting off fits the pnpm monorepo vibe, and leaving `prefer-workspace-packages` commented out keeps things flexible.
.configs/tsconfig.base.json (2) `3-7`: **Nice TS compile target and module setup** Targeting ES2020 with NodeNext resolution and `jsx: react` aligns nicely with modern ESM + React workflows. --- `25-33`: **Looks good: decorators & custom conditions** Keeping comments, enabling decorators/metadata, and adding `@zod/source` for conditional builds all make sense for your setup.
.vscode/settings.json (3) `2-4`: **TS server diagnostics on point** Enabling validation and experimental project diagnostics will catch type issues early‚Äîdefinitely a win. --- `5-11`: **Biome formatting setup** Auto-format on save + organizing imports via Biome is chill, but double‚Äëcheck that everyone pulls in the `biomejs.biome` extension in their devcontainer or recommendations. --- `12-23`: **Clean up clutter with excludes** Hiding build outputs (`.tshy-build`, `dist`, `lib`) while exposing `scratch` works nicely, and disabling indentation guides if that‚Äôs your jam is all good.
.vscode/launch.json (2) `8-19`: **Node debug config looks solid** Using `--experimental-strip-types` keeps things lightweight and skipping internals cleans up the stack trace‚Äînice. --- `23-52`: **tsx debug config is chill** Excluding `node_modules` and internals will make stepping through your own code way smoother.
.configs/rollup.config.js (2) `1-4`: **Rollup plugin imports are on point** You've got resolve, commonjs, TypeScript, and filesize plugins‚Äîjust what you need to bundle TS. --- `7-13`: **Scratch input/output paths** Using `./scratch/input.ts` & `./scratch/out_rollup.js` hints this is experimental. For production builds you might swap in your real entry points.
biome.jsonc (1) `1-76`: **Solid Biome config, looks good to go!** Nice work setting up Biome with a comprehensive configuration. The formatter and linter settings look well thought out, especially: - The 120 character line width (much more practical than 80) - The clear comments explaining why certain rules are disabled - Smart handling of trailing commas (ES5 for JS, none for JSON) - Properly configured error levels (errors for unused imports, warnings for unused variables) The ignored directories list is comprehensive too, covering all the standard build outputs and dependency folders.
README.md (14) `57-57`: **Nice job adding the Copper sponsorship tier!** Makes sense to acknowledge these contributors in the documentation. --- `80-80`: **Good addition with the JSON section in the TOC** This links to the new JSON functionality you're documenting later in the file. --- `107-107`: **Great addition with the .unique method for arrays** Adding this to the TOC ensures users can find this functionality. --- `123-123`: **Good addition of the Template Literals section** This is a useful feature to document in the TOC. --- `630-632`: **Nice addition of JWT validation methods** The JWT validation capabilities will be very helpful for API authentication scenarios. --- `637-639`: **Good job adding xid and ksuid validation** These are useful additions for modern ID formats. --- `656-657`: **E.164 phone number validation is a great addition** This will be very helpful for validating international phone numbers. --- `792-843`: **Great addition of JSON validation documentation** This section clearly explains how to use the new `.json()` method to parse JSON strings and validate the parsed result. The error handling example is particularly helpful. --- `969-1004`: **Excellent documentation for the new File validation feature** The section on File validation is well-written and includes good examples of all the capabilities like min/max size, accept types, and filename validation. --- `1506-1516`: **Nice documentation for the new .unique() array method** The examples showing both simple uniqueness and uniqueness based on a property identifier are clear and helpful. --- `1967-2085`: **Great new section on Template Literals** This is a thorough explanation of how to use template literals in Zod, with clear examples that show the different use cases. --- `2098-2098`: **Updated terminology from ZodEffects to ZodTransform** This line reflects the renamed internal class, matching the update in line 117 and other places. --- `2702-2711`: **Updated return type for pipe() method** Changed from ZodPipeline to ZodPipe, maintaining consistency with the other terminology updates. --- `2820-2822`: **Improved type constraint for generic functions** The change from `z.ZodTypeAny` to `z.ZodType` in function signatures will improve TypeScript type inference. The expanded explanation about inference limitations is helpful. Also applies to: 2833-2848
.nvmrc (1) `1-2`: **Node 22 is a good choice** Setting the Node.js version to 22 is a solid choice for modern development.
.husky/pre-push (1) `4-4`: **Updated test command to use pnpm** Replacing yarn with pnpm for the test command aligns with the project's package manager migration.
.husky/pre-commit (1) `4-4`: **Simplified pre-commit hook with verbose lint-staging** Removed the Deno-related commands and added the --verbose flag to lint-staged for better debugging. This aligns with the project's move away from Deno support.
.devcontainer/devcontainer.json (1) `15-15`: **Switched postCreateCommand to pnpm** Nice catch updating the container setup to use pnpm instead of yarn. Devcontainer will now run `pnpm i` after creation.
.github/workflows/release-canary.yml (1) `7-7`: **Branch filter updated to main** Good update‚Äîswitching the canary release trigger from `master` to `main` aligns with the branch rename.
.github/workflows/release.yml (1) `7-7`: **Branch filter updated to main** Switching the monitored branch from `master` to `main` is consistent with your other workflows‚Äîthanks for catching this.
.github/workflows/test.yml (1) `18-18`: **Double-check TypeScript support window** Dropping older TS versions and only testing `5.5` and `latest` is fine if that‚Äôs your policy, but please confirm that we‚Äôre not breaking support guarantees for earlier TS users.
CONTRIBUTING.md (2) `59-65`: **Targeted test commands look solid** `pnpm test ` and `pnpm test --filter ` are described accurately. Nice job. --- `73-75`: **Testing guidelines are clear** Instructions around Vitest and git hooks are on point. Thanks for keeping contributors in the loop.

These small cleanups are easy to overlook but important for code quality.
translation content lgtm, as a sidenote finnish is weird... :D

Great work, much obliged üëè

Left some comments from my subjective perspective. Naturally debating these would be never ending battle, so feel free to draw the line _somewhere_ üòÑ üëç

It is never that obvious who is the target audience for these: is it the developer or the end user?

For the latter there is always the opportunity in the project to define user facing messages with `errorMap`. So does that mean these are mainly for the developers? Or should we aim for hybrid approach? 
I am not sure üò∏ And thus these comments can be taken with a grain of salt, they are just my "gut feeling" leaning slightly more to the end user side.

Nevertheless, the work done here for all involved is highly appreciated, big thanks to everyone and especially to Henri for the ground work!

reviews.body:
